title: QAPI (Quality Assurance) Schema
description:
Create Comprehensive Quality Assurance and Performance Tracking Database Schema

Design and implement a production-ready database schema to capture, track, and analyze quality assurance metrics and performance improvement initiatives across the organization.

Core Entities:

Quality Metrics Storage:
- Define tables/collections for tracking key quality indicators including defect rates, test coverage percentages, mean time to resolution (MTTR), customer-reported issues, and automated test results
- Support flexible metric types with extensible schema to accommodate new KPIs without structural changes
- Include time-series capabilities with granular timestamp tracking for trend analysis
- Store metric values with context (product area, environment, release version, team)
- Add threshold definitions for alerting and SLA tracking

Improvement Initiatives Tracking:
- Create structure for initiatives with title, description, objectives, and success criteria
- Track initiative lifecycle (proposed, approved, in-progress, completed, cancelled)
- Assign ownership with team and individual contributor fields
- Store timelines with planned vs actual start/completion dates
- Link to related documentation, tickets, or external project management tools

Relationships and Impact Analysis:
- Establish many-to-many relationships between metrics and initiatives
- Track before/after metric snapshots to quantify initiative impact
- Support initiative dependencies and prerequisite tracking
- Enable correlation analysis between different metric types

Data Organization and Categorization:
- Product area/component hierarchy for filtering and grouping
- Severity levels (critical, high, medium, low) with clear definitions
- Priority rankings for initiatives and defects
- Team/department assignments with organizational hierarchy support
- Tags or labels for flexible cross-cutting categorization

Temporal and Historical Tracking:
- Time-series schema optimized for daily, weekly, monthly aggregations
- Historical snapshots with configurable retention policies
- Version tracking for metric definitions as they evolve
- Audit log for all changes with user attribution and timestamps

Query Optimization:
- Define composite indexes for common access patterns (time ranges + category + team)
- Partial indexes for active/recent data to improve dashboard performance
- Materialized views or summary tables for expensive aggregations
- Partition strategy for time-series data to manage growth

Data Integrity:
- Foreign key constraints between related entities
- Check constraints for valid status transitions and value ranges
- Unique constraints to prevent duplicate metric recordings
- Referential integrity for team/user references
- Required field validation (NOT NULL constraints)

Metadata and Audit Fields:
- created_at, updated_at timestamps with timezone support
- created_by, updated_by user references
- soft_delete flag with deleted_at and deleted_by tracking
- version number for optimistic locking
- data_source field to track origin (manual entry, API, automation)

Technical Specifications:
- Choose between relational (PostgreSQL, MySQL) or document (MongoDB) database based on query patterns and scalability needs
- Define JSON/JSONB fields for flexible metric-specific attributes
- Include comments/annotations on schema objects for documentation
- Specify data types with appropriate precision (DECIMAL for percentages, BIGINT for counts)
- Plan for horizontal scaling with sharding strategy if needed

Integration and Extensibility:
- API-friendly structure with consistent ID schemes (UUID vs auto-increment)
- Webhook/event table for triggering notifications on threshold breaches
- Import/export schema for bulk data operations
- Connection points for CI/CD tools, test frameworks, and monitoring systems
- Support for calculated/derived metrics based on raw data

Deliverables:
- Complete DDL scripts or schema definition files
- Entity-relationship diagram (ERD) showing all tables and relationships
- Data dictionary documenting each field's purpose, constraints, and sample values
- Index strategy documentation with rationale
- Sample queries demonstrating common reporting use cases
- Migration plan for initial deployment and future schema evolution

Success Criteria:
- Schema supports all identified metric types without requiring structural changes
- Dashboard queries execute in under 2 seconds for typical time ranges
- Data integrity maintained through constraints and validation
- Audit trail provides complete change history
- Schema can scale to millions of metric data points without performance degradation
